intro: Cacalia jatrophoides, commonly known as the hairy beggar's ticks, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble daisies. The plant features hairy stems and leaves, which contribute to its common name. It produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in the summer months. Cacalia jatrophoides is often found in moist, disturbed soils along roadsides and in open woods.
